para.text: In this chapter, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Terms Defined.
"Board" means the Maryland Board of Nursing.
"Certificate" means a certificate issued by the Board to practice as a nursing assistant in this State.
"Certified medicine aide (CMA)" means an individual certified in good standing as an active CNA who:
Satisfies the requirements of COMAR 10.39.03.02; and
Is further certified by the Board to accept delegation of administration of certain medications.
Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA).
"Certified nursing assistant (CNA)" means an individual who is certified by the Board to routinely perform nursing tasks delegated by an RN or LPN for compensation.
"Certified nursing assistant (CNA)" does not include:
A medication assistant or a medication technician as defined in Health Occupations Article, §8-6A-01(f), Annotated Code of Maryland; or
An individual who merely provides assistance with activities of daily living unless the client's needs are such that adverse health consequences are predictable.
"Controlled schedule drugs" means drugs listed as Schedule I, II, III, IV, or V controlled dangerous substances under Criminal Law Article, §§5-402 — 5-406, Annotated Code of Maryland.
"Geriatric nursing assistant (GNA)" has the meaning stated in COMAR 10.39.01.
"Licensed practical nurse (LPN)" has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §8-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.
"Registered nurse (RN)" has the meaning stated in Health Occupations Article, §8-101, Annotated Code of Maryland.
An applicant for certification as a CMA shall provide evidence satisfactory to the Board of meeting the following requirements:
Current certification by the Board as an active CNA in good standing;
Current employment and work experience as required by the Board in a setting acceptable to the Board, including:
Current employment and 2 years of full-time experience as a CNA in a facility licensed under 42 CFR Part 483 et seq.; or
Current employment and 1 year of full-time experience as a GNA in a facility licensed in Maryland under COMAR 10.07.02; and
Successful completion as evidenced by a certificate of completion from a Board-approved CMA training program.

The community college shall submit verification of successful completion of the CMA training program to the Board within 5 business days after completion of the program in a manner prescribed by the Board.
Before renewal of certification as a CMA, and subject to the requirements in Health Occupations Article, §8-6A-08, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 10.39.01.06, the applicant shall:
Successfully complete a Board-approved 8-hour medicine aide continuing education program as required by Regulation .03B of this chapter; and
Provide satisfactory evidence of completion of 100 hours of practice as a certified medicine aide in the 2-year period preceding the date of renewal.
Medicine Aide Course Curriculum. The Board shall approve a CMA program that:
Requires a candidate for admission to the program have current employment and work experience as set forth in Regulation .02A(2) of this chapter;
Requires before admission that a candidate have a positive recommendation from the director of nursing in the facility where the candidate is employed;

Is at least 60 hours in length with a minimum of 30 clock hours devoted to theoretical instruction and a minimum of 30 clock hours of supervised clinical training experience in a facility licensed under COMAR 10.07.02;
Includes instruction in both theory and clinical regarding all approved routes of medication administration and the scope of responsibility of the CMA; and
Includes each of the following subjects:
Responsibilities and limitations of the CMA;
Drug standards, references, and resources;
Legislation concerning drug utilization;
Characteristics of the elderly client or client with multiple handicaps;
Sources and purposes of drugs;
Dosage forms and methods of administration;
Drug life;
The medication order;
The pharmacy label;
The administration of nonparenteral medications;
Procedures and techniques for administering drugs;
Drug classification, related health problems, and patient care responsibilities;
Drug solutions and measurements; and
Monitoring side effects of drugs and drug interactions.
Medicine Aide Continuing Education Curriculum. Continuing education courses required for continued listing as a CMA as required in Regulation .02C of this chapter shall contain:
A 3-hour core content that includes:
Current State regulations related to the role of the medicine aide;
Uses, actions, and possible interactions of and related precautions for current medications used in the care of the geriatric patient;
New care procedures; and
Resources available to the medicine aide which clarify and expand the knowledge of the medicine aide; and
3 hours on at least three of the following topics:
Documentation;
Nutrition;
The physiological system of the geriatric patient;
De-institutionalization of the intellectually disabled or psychiatric patient; or
Other aspects of pharmacology; and
2 hours of assessment testing administered at the completion of the continuing education course.
The CMA may be delegated medication administration by the RN or LPN under the following conditions:
The licensed nursing supervision requirements in Regulation .05 of this chapter have been met;
The CMA is assigned to administer medication;
There is a written medication order;
The CMA is physically present on a continuing basis in the unit of care to accomplish the following as instructed and directed by the RN or LPN:
Monitor the therapeutic effects of the medication;
Observe and report untoward effects of the medication;
Report observed changes in client behavior and clinical status; and
Withhold administration of the medication if necessary.
The CMA may perform the following RN or LPN delegated nursing functions:
Prepare, administer, and chart medications administered:
Orally;
By nebulizer, metered dose inhalant, and, in the case of oxygen, by nasal cannula or mask;
Topically, excluding wound or decubitus site care;
By suppository; and
By eye, ear, and nose drops;
Prepare, administer, and chart:
Nonlegend PRN medications; and
Controlled schedule drugs after the RN or LPN:
Makes a bedside assessment of the patient;
Documents the assessment; and
Gives permission to the CMA to administer that medication; and
When the licensed nurse delegating medication administration provides access to the controlled schedule drug cabinet, sign for and administer controlled schedule drugs.

section.heading: Supervision.
section.text: The CMA may administer medications when:

para.text: In a setting licensed under COMAR 10.07.02, the licensed nurse is physically present and immediately available on the unit of care in which the client resides to provide direct supervision of any client who receives medication administered by the CMA; and
In a setting licensed under 42 CFR Part 483 et seq., the licensed nurse is on-site and physically available to the CMA and the CMA administers medications only to clients whose clinical status is:
Chronic;
Stable;
Uncomplicated; and
Permitting placement in the community.

section.heading: Unlawful Delegation.
section.text: The RN or LPN may not delegate the following duties to the CMA:

para.text: Transcription of original physician orders to medication and treatment administration records, charts, or Kardexes;
Charge level responsibilities, including receiving instructions for or being assigned to such responsibilities;
Administration of medication to clients whose clinical status is acutely unstable, complex, or medically fragile in a setting licensed under 42 CFR Part 483 et seq.;
Administration of medication by way of the following routes:
Injection;
Intravenous route; and
By way of a tube inserted in a cavity of the body, including nasogastric or gastrostomy tube feeding;
Client teaching;
Acceptance of verbal or telephone orders; and
Responsibility for maintaining possession of the keys or access code to the locked container for controlled schedule drugs.
